titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Walked an hour in the mall this morning, and bathed afterwards— I am obliged to vary my bathing hour according to the tide— Brought up my account books— Call’d at the Branch Bank— Mr: Boylston was here— Read this afternoon in the 8th: volume of Montaigne— The Chapter’s upon Coaches, and on the Art of holding conference

2. Bathed after breakfast this morning, to accommodate with the time of the full tide. At 12. had a meeting of the Directors of Neponset Bridge; agreed upon an assessment of 40 dollars to a share to be paid 1. September— In the afternoon read Montaigne’s Chapter on Vanity—treating of death, of travelling, and various other subjects, and scarce a word about vanity— Walk’d in the Mall, with Caroline— Mr: Shaw went out to Quincy this afternoon—and return’d at Night.

3. Second day, the thermometer at 90— And that oppressive heat, which since my return from Europe, I have found almost insupportable— It disqualifies me for every species of labour, and reduces me to a state of absolute idleness— Bathed at noon. Read this afternoon the remainder of his Chapter on Vanity, and also that on the management of the will; which closes the 8th: volume— In this he takes notice himself of his desultory stile, and confesses that most of his remarks have little apparent connection with the titles of his chapter— Yet some connection they always have, he affirms, and thinks it will be perceived by all but indigent readers; in which description I must of course be classed. In the Chapter on Vanity, there are some excellent observations on Party-Spirit, on travelling, and on Death— Now all these doubtless have their hitch upon some corner of Vanity, because the preacher says All is Vanity— Caroline Spent the evening at Mrs: H. G. Otis’s— Club at Dr: Spooner’s— Quincy has got home.— Mr: Shaw went to Atkinson.
4. Third day of extreme heat— Bathed at noon; as did Mr: Emerson, whom I met at the wharf. Dined at Dr: Dexter’s with a company of about fifteen gentlemen— Walk’d in the Mall, this Evening.—

5. The weather has moderated; though still very warm— Bathed between 1. and 2. p.m. and met Mr: Emerson— Read this afternoon— Montaigne Vol: 9. Of lameness. A singular subject and singularly treated— Also of the countenance, or physiognomy.— Evening not very well.
6. The day principally rainy— Dexter came in from Quincy however, and I went out with him this afternoon— Read a little in the forenoon, but wrote nothing.
7. Heard Mr: Whitney— Read some of Sevigne’s letters, at the close of the third, and beginning of the fourth volumes— My Uncle Adams, Mr: Beale, and the two Messrs: Greenleaf’s, here in the Evening.

8. Return’d to Boston this morning— Went down to Neponset Bridge on my way— It is advancing somewhat slowly.— Called at Mr: Quincy’s Office, after I arrived in town. Finished reading Montaigne’s Essays this afternoon— At the close of which are some letters, and works of his friend De la Boetie— Upon the whole I am glad to have got through the Essays, though I doubt whether I have got any thing valuable from them.

9. Had an ill night, and was unwell, the whole of this day— Forenoon principally occupied in looking up papers to be returned to their owners.— In the afternoon, read Montaigne’s letters, and his friend La Boëtie’s discourse against the government of one— Had letters from Mr: Gore and Mr: Pitcairn.

10. Mr: James Lovell called upon me this forenoon, and in a conversation of more than three hours, explained to me his ideas and intentions with regard to certain publications which he has commenced, and attempted in the newspapers of this town— Mr: & Mrs: J. Gardner likewise called— This afternoon I read the Preface of Mlle: de Gournay, to Montaigne’s Essays, and some of the Judgments and Critiques upon them in the tenth volume— Walk’d in the Mall, with Mr: Gardner. Evening at Club at Dr: Warren’s. Mr: Shaw return’d this evening from Atkinson.

11. Bathed this morning before breakfast— Mr: Boylston called on me this forenoon— Saw Mr: Hall, Judge Davis and Mr: Gay, who agreed to meet to-morrow, at noon upon the case of Mr: Murray, and the Union Bank— This afternoon finished Montaigne.— Read in Scarron’s Roman Comique.

12. The referees in the case of Murray, against the Union Bank Directors met at noon, and the subject was discussed and left with them— This afternoon, I went out with Mrs: Adams, and George to Mr: Boylston’s, and took tea— Mrs: Warren and her daughter, Mr: D. Sears and his son were there— We return’d to Boston in the Evening.

13. Dexter came to town with the Chaise for me; but I went out with Mr: Gardner— From his house in Milton I walk’d to Quincy; got there at about 8 in the Evening, and found that my mother was so ill that I could not see her this night— She has been so the greatest part of the week. My father is in great affliction, and strongly apprehensive of the issue.

14. Bathed this morning at the wharf below Mr: Black’s— Heard Mr: Whitney— Spent the remainder of the day and evening, principally with my father— Read little, and wrote nothing.— My mother continues ill, without abatement of the alarming symptoms— In extreme pain from a large and highly inflamed tumour, on the spot where sometime since she had applied a blister.— Mr: Foster was here with his wife, and return’d to Boston at Night.

15. My mother suffers less pain than for some days past; but without any appearance of a favourable turn to her disorder— I rode out with my father on horseback this forenoon, and viewed the lands which he has conveyed to me— Mrs: Smith and Mrs: Otis came from Boston to see my mother; as did my wife, with Mr: Shaw— They returned this evening.— I pass’d most of my time with my father.

16. I intended to have returned this morning to Boston, but at my mother’s desire, stayed with my father— Rode out with him, down upon his farm this forenoon; and drew the form of a conveyance in which they both joined, of my mother’s share in the Quincy Estate, and of her Medford farm— The first to me, in trust to the use of my father and mother during their joint lives, and to the survivor; remainder to myself in fee— The Medford Estate is to be conveyed in the same manner to my brother Thomas— For My Sister Smith— My brother Charles’s children, and Louisa Smith, my mother told me she should provide, by certain stock in the hands and name of Dr: Tufts— Mrs: Cranch was here last Night, and again this day— I read some letters of Sevigné, some of the correspondence in Pope’s works, and some of Dr: Aikin’s letters to his son—

17. Returned to Boston this morning, with Mr: T. Greenleaf; Dr: Warren went out to Quincy, to see my mother— I called on him in the evening just after his return; he had laid open the tumour, which has been so painful, and from its appearance, gave me little encouragement to hope for her recovery.— Without considering the case as absolutely desperate he thinks it in the highest degree threatening— I pass’d
the evening with the club at Mr: Welles’s— There was a Mr: Coffin there; who is at the head of a new College, in the State of Tennessee, for which he is here to sollicit subscriptions— Mr: Townsend called on me this morning; and dined with us— Mr: Gardner called on me this afternoon.

18. I wrote letters to my brother Thomas, and to Mr: Hellen— To the former, to communicate the state of my mother’s health— To Mr: Hellen, requesting him to make arrangements, as to the terms on which we are to reside at his house when at Washington— At about 1. p.m. I bathed at the wharf behind the alms house— Dr: Welsh called on me this evening; just returned from Quincy, where he left Mrs: Welsh— His account of my mother, is a glimmer of hope better than that of Dr: Warren; but I dare not indulge it.

19. The heaviness of heart and of spirits, which I am unable to resist, disqualifies me from every proper occupation; and I aggravate the evils, which I am unable to remove, by that of absolute idleness— Mr: Boylston, Mr: Murray the clergyman, and Mr: Gardner called on me this forenoon— The last, to tell me he had been last Evening at Quincy, and seen my mother— His account agrees with that of Dr: Welsh; and he saw her only an hour or two later— I do nothing, but read; and that without system or profit—

20. Saw Mr: Quincy at his Office, and called upon Judge Davis— Dexter came in from Quincy, for me, but I went out with Mr: Gardner— It was about 8 in the evening when I got there. I found Doctor Welsh there.— He had landed from his boat, and walked up— My mother continues in undiminished danger.

21. Heard Mr: Ware of Hingham— On our ignorance of the future— And on moral charity— Read in Madame de Sevigné’s letters and finished the fourth volume— This afternoon, my Sister Smith arrived from New-York, after being detained four days in quarantine at Newport.

22. Doctor Welsh speaks this morning more doubtfully of my mother’s recovery, than he has done before. She has very little hope herself— I returned to Boston with Mrs: Welsh— Found my two children both unwell. Read a little this afternoon; but was too idle.— Mr: B. Shaw called on me.
23. Dr: Kilham called; returned me the first volume of Reaumur’s history of Insects, and borrowed the 2d: 3d: and 4th.— Mr: Bracket also called— I read but little and wrote nothing.

24. Bathed, at the alms’ house wharf before breakfast. Sat out to walk to Cambridge, to attend the meeting of the Academy— On the bridge, Dr: Eustis in a Chair overtook me, and offered me a seat, which I accepted— He was going to an exhibition; but had mistaken the day— The exhibition is to be to-morrow. The meeting of the Academy, was more numerous than usual— Several Communications were made. My father was present— My mother being a little better— After the meeting we dined at President Willard’s— Dr: Lathrop and Dr: Warren also dined there— The rest of the Gentlemen dined at Judge Dana’s. My father to take me home, return’d through Boston, and stop’d a few minutes at my house— We called at Judge Dana’s, as we came along— Club this evening at my house— Very fully attended. Mr: Coffin, the President of a New College in the State of Tennessee, and Mr: Nichols from Philadelphia, were here.

25. Revising my translation of Juvenal’s 7th: Satire— Dined with Mr: Daniel D. Rogers— Who is a descendant from John Rogers, the man of the primer— Mr: J. Joy, Mr: Channing and Mr: Quincy there— I agreed to go out with him to-morrow. Mrs: Adams and Caroline unwell.

26. Went out to Quincy this morning with Mr: Quincy; to meet a Committee of the Town, and agree upon the parts of the old Town road which are to be discontinued, on the opening of the road to Neponsit bridge— The Committee, from the town, my Uncle Adams, Mr: Jos: Baxter, and Mr: Daniel Greenleaf agreed to cede the land of the road to be discontinued, to the proprietors of the bridge— They to indemnify the individuals who have given land for the new road— We returned to dinner at my father’s— My Mother who for some days had been apparently better, since yesterday afternoon has relapsed into extreme weakness— We returned to Boston this afternoon— I called at Dr: Welsh’s, to whom they had written last Night, to request he would go out, and see my mother— He received the letter too late this morning, but will go out to-morrow.

27. I went out this afternoon as far as Milton, in the Quincy Stage. Stopp’d at Mr: Gardner’s; and walk’d the remainder of the way— He went part of it with me— I found Mr: Jackson at his house. He had dined with Mr: Robbins— Professor Tappan died this morning.— I was to have attended the valedictory of the highest Class at the Latin School, but came too late.

28. My Mother remains in the same state of dangerous illness that she has been these three weeks— Heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury; who dined with us— As did Mrs: B. Shaw of Boston— Mr: Whitney called in the afternoon. My Uncle Adams in the Evening.— Read some of Sevigné’s letters Vol: 5.— Bathed at the wharf this morning—

29. Breakfasted with Mr: Gardner, and afterwards return’d with him to Boston— The weather, which for some days, has been warm in extreme, this day is more moderate— Walk, this Evening— I have read the Roman Comique of Scarron— He left it unfinished— Wrote only the first two parts— They answer the title of the book— They contain much humour and gaiety. The characters are well drawn and preserved— The incidents are diverting and ludicrous. The story is interesting— There are two continuations, in the third volume—by different hands— One of which still leaves the work unfinished— Both are unfit to be compared with the first parts— The one that finishes, flat to an excess— The other better, but without any one good feature of Scarron— The whole book is interspersed with novels or tales, which interrupt the course, and weaken the effect of the principal story.

30. Mr: Isaac Smith, Judge Davis, Mr: Boylston, and Mr: Quincy dined with us— Walk’d this evening with Mrs: Adams and Caroline— Mrs: A— at bed time was taken violently ill— I called Dr: Welsh. After an hour or two of great pain she obtained greater ease—

31. Commencement day— Which however I did not attend.— Mrs: Adams quite unwell— I bathed at the wharf this forenoon.— Read le Belier, a tale—by Count Antoine Hamilton. It is a satirical imitation of the Persian and Arabian Tales, written with Spirit and pleasantry.

Day. I rise between 6 and 7. Sometimes bathe; and at others, pass the time with George (who now sleeps with me) till breakfast time— Forenoon, reading or writing as occasion happens— Go out from one P.M. untill 2. Dine— Read for amusement after dinner, untill about sunset— Walk an hour in the Mall— Remainder of the Evening at home.
